category_summary:
**Anthropic** dominated discussions with major [interpretability research](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-312563429669) on the 'Assistant Axis' - mapping how language models represent personas and identifying safety-relevant [drift patterns](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-b731497eee85) that can lead to harmful outputs in open-weights models.

- **John Carmack** delivered [deep technical analysis](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-a74cd5786099) of the Cautious Weight Decay optimization paper, bringing legendary engineering credibility to ML research review
- **Simon Willison** [reported](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-421aefadc792) that **Cursor** built a functional web browser using agentic coding in weeks, calling it 'remarkably capable' and demonstrating AI's software engineering potential
- **Sakana AI** [introduced RePo research](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-a0cd063a56dc) addressing fundamental context limitations in LLMs
- **Ethan Mollick** provided original [quantitative analysis](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-c6db5766282a) on **GPT-5.2** capabilities and [pushed back](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-dae3232162f3) on AI bubble narratives, noting a billion people use AI weekly

Practical AI coding concerns surfaced: 68% of developers [reportedly spend](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-415dc9d6a58a) more time debugging AI-generated code than writing new code. **Andriy Burkov's** [viral thesis](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-3bd8fa7b5173) that unfixable AI code should simply be regenerated from scratch sparked debate about emerging 'vibecoding' workflows. **Neel Nanda** [offered rare insight](/?date=2026-01-20&category=social#item-ece02d92c38b) into the difficulty of deploying safety research in production at **Google DeepMind**.

items.title:
#PaperADay 7
Cautious Weight Decay
https://t.co/EzgZbK4WRJ

This is a 36 page paper about a very sim...
items.content:
#PaperADay 7
Cautious Weight Decay
https://t.co/EzgZbK4WRJ

This is a 36 page paper about a very simple idea:
Don‚Äôt apply weight decay when it is in opposition to the current optimizer step.

If the step is moving the weight farther from zero, there is no decay. If the step is towards zero, decay moves it in faster.

They spent 20,000 H100 GPU hours (about $60k!) testing this across multiple optimizers and models, and it looks like it is basically always a modest improvement, with no changes to any hyperparameters.

My current models use weight norm on most of the parameters, but there are still some with traditional weight decay. A first test with this idea does seem to be a tiny improvement, but I will need to do more runs to have confidence in it.

Two modifications of the idea come to mind:

Use the current gradient instead of the optimizer step (which includes momentum) for masking, as in https://t.co/Q7yiRAyw19. If using a cautious optimizer, explicitly masking the optimizer step before calculating cautious weight decay would do this automatically.

Weight decay is an exponential effect, which mixes with a linear learning rate. It might be interesting to just have a larger learning rate when the step is heading towards zero than away from it, which would do similar things, but with different learning dynamics.

items.summary: John Carmack's #PaperADay review of 'Cautious Weight Decay' paper - a technique that prevents weight decay when opposing the optimizer step. items.content_html:
#PaperADay 7

Cautious Weight Decay

https://t.co/EzgZbK4WRJ

This is a 36 page paper about a very simple idea:

Don‚Äôt apply weight decay when it is in opposition to the current optimizer step.

If the step is moving the weight farther from zero, there is no decay. If the step is towards zero, decay moves it in faster.

They spent 20,000 H100 GPU hours (about $60k!) testing this across multiple optimizers and models, and it looks like it is basically always a modest improvement, with no changes to any hyperparameters.

My current models use weight norm on most of the parameters, but there are still some with traditional weight decay. A first test with this idea does seem to be a tiny improvement, but I will need to do more runs to have confidence in it.

Two modifications of the idea come to mind:

Use the current gradient instead of the optimizer step (which includes momentum) for masking, as in https://t.co/Q7yiRAyw19. If using a cautious optimizer, explicitly masking the optimizer step before calculating cautious weight decay would do this automatically.

Weight decay is an exponential effect, which mixes with a linear learning rate. It might be interesting to just have a larger learning rate when the step is heading towards zero than away from it, which would do similar things, but with different learning dynamics.

items.title: If there is a financial bubble in AI, which is not in any way clear, there is no "use bubble" - a bi...
items.content: If there is a financial bubble in AI, which is not in any way clear, there is no "use bubble" - a billion people use AI weekly. It isn't going away. Even if every frontier lab went under (but Google, which can't), AI development would continue with the same people at other firms

items.title:
Introducing RePo: Language Models with Context Re-Positioning

Standard LLMs force a rigid linear st...
items.content:
Introducing RePo: Language Models with Context Re-Positioning

Standard LLMs force a rigid linear structure on context, treating physical proximity as relevance. Cognitive Load Theory suggests this is inefficient‚Äîmodels waste capacity managing noise instead of reasoning.

arxiv.org/abs/2512.14391

68% of developers say they spend more time debugging AI code than writing new code.

(According to a survey of 500 software engineering leaders and practitioners.)

AI coding assistants help us write code faster, but they increase the amount of insecure and broken code we ship.

items.title: Get "Mathematics of Machine Learning" here: https://t.co/07exFk5LqL by @TivadarDanka v/ @PacktDataML...
items.content:
Get "Mathematics of Machine Learning" here: https://t.co/07exFk5LqL by @TivadarDanka v/ @PacktDataML 
‚Äî
Author‚Äôs GitHub: https://t.co/2ENjzhr35C
‚Äî
Here is my review:

ùóßùóµùó≤ ùó¶ùó≤ùòÅ ùó¢ùó≥ ùó†ùóÆùòÅùóµùó≤ùó∫ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùóπ ùóîùóπùó¥ùóºùóøùó∂ùòÅùóµùó∫ùòÄ ùóßùóµùóÆùòÅ ùóüùó≤ùóÆùóøùóª ùóôùóøùóºùó∫ ùóòùòÖùóΩùó≤ùóøùó∂ùó≤ùóªùó∞ùó≤

This massive book is incredible, with its comprehensive coverage of numerous fields of mathematics and their intersection with the world of AI, data science, and machine learning (AI+DSML). I remember the very first time that I encountered machine learning. This was 20+ years ago, and that was already after 20+ years of being drenched in advanced mathematics as an astrophysicist. 

That first encounter of mine with ML was this definition: "Machine learning is the set of mathematical algorithms that learn from experience" (slightly paraphrased from the original quote by Tom Mitchell, CMU). That definition surprised me, confused me, motivated me, and changed the course of my career from astrophysics into AI+DSML. 

This book by Tivadar Danka captures the full meaning of that definition. The book covers thoroughly the many areas and domains of mathematics through which patterns in data are detected, described, learned, and recognized - all for the benefit of powering ML and AI algorithms, applications, and aspirations. 

This book will motivate you, surprise you, and inspire you in many ways, no matter what level of mathematics has (or has not) already propelled your career journey. There is room for all of us to grow. 

This is a great book, worthy to sit on everyone's desktop, ready to help you explore and exploit the full set of mathematical algorithms that learn from experience. 

The book is accompanied by a rich GitHub code repository of Jupyter notebooks. Learn by doing! Do by learning!

Disclosure: the publisher provided me with a free review copy of the book.

Some still don't understand (I know, it's hard and will take time) that manually fixing AI-generated code isn't going to happen.

The non-fixable code will simply be regenerated from scratch based on the spec and unit tests.

items.title:
Claude Cowork is great at reading markdown files, and not great at reading PDFs üìë

I made a simple c...
items.content:
Claude Cowork is great at reading markdown files, and not great at reading PDFs üìë

I made a simple command that lets you batch parse PDFs -> markdown in an output folder, so you can just point Cowork to it.

It lets the agent understand massive amounts of docs much more quickly and accurately (much lower hallucination errors over complex visuals, tables, etc.)

In this example, after I parsed 100+ Supreme Court filings into markdown, cowork is able to return the answer in seconds.

My wrapper is a simple extension of our very own semtools. Very DIY, will clean this up:  https://t.co/Et8Iwvx9Dq
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu shares workflow: batch parse PDFs to markdown for Claude Cowork to reduce hallucinations on complex documents with tables/visuals; demo shows 100+ Supreme Court filings parsed and queried in seconds

Claude Cowork is great at reading markdown files, and not great at reading PDFs üìë

I made a simple command that lets you batch parse PDFs -> markdown in an output folder, so you can just point Cowork to it.

In this example, after I parsed 100+ Supreme Court filings into markdown, cowork is able to return the answer in seconds.

items.title:

"AI Ag...
items.content:
See the latest book from @AltoValentina, released by @PacktDataML at https://t.co/yPRfXTozGF

"AI Agents in Practice ‚Äî Design, Implement, and Scale Autonomous #AI Systems for Production"

Book Description (from Amazon):

As AI agents evolve to take on complex tasks and operate autonomously, you need to learn how to build these next-generation systems. Author Valentina Alto brings practical, industry-grounded expertise in AI Agents in Practice to help you go beyond simple chatbots and create AI agents that plan, reason, collaborate, and solve real-world problems using large language models (LLMs) and the latest open-source frameworks.

In this book, you'll get a comparative tour of leading AI agent frameworks such as LangChain and LangGraph, covering each tool's strengths, ideal use cases, and how to apply them in real-world projects. Through step-by-step examples, you‚Äôll learn how to construct single-agent and multi-agent architectures using proven design patterns to orchestrate AI agents working together. Case studies across industries will show you how AI agents drive value in real-world scenarios, while guidance on responsible AI will help you implement ethical guardrails from day one. The chapters also set the stage with a brief history of AI agents, from early rule-based systems to today's LLM-driven autonomous agents, so you understand how we got here and where the field is headed.

By the end of this book, you'll have the practical skills, design insights, and ethical foresight to build and deploy AI agents that truly make an impact.

"AI Agents in Practice ‚Äî Design, Implement, and Scale Autonomous #AI Systems for Production"

Book Description (from Amazon):

As AI agents evolve to take on complex tasks and operate autonomously, you need to learn how to build these next-generation systems. Author Valentina Alto brings practical, industry-grounded expertise in AI Agents in Practice to help you go beyond simple chatbots and create AI agents that plan, reason, collaborate, and solve real-world problems using large language models (LLMs) and the latest open-source frameworks.

In this book, you'll get a comparative tour of leading AI agent frameworks such as LangChain and LangGraph, covering each tool's strengths, ideal use cases, and how to apply them in real-world projects. Through step-by-step examples, you‚Äôll learn how to construct single-agent and multi-agent architectures using proven design patterns to orchestrate AI agents working together. Case studies across industries will show you how AI agents drive value in real-world scenarios, while guidance on responsible AI will help you implement ethical guardrails from day one. The chapters also set the stage with a brief history of AI agents, from early rule-based systems to today's LLM-driven autonomous agents, so you understand how we got here and where the field is headed.

By the end of this book, you'll have the practical skills, design insights, and ethical foresight to build and deploy AI agents that truly make an impact.

items.title: One-third of AI-generated code contains at least one security vulnerability. Faster AI-generated cod...
items.content:
One-third of AI-generated code contains at least one security vulnerability. Faster AI-generated code is turning into faster tech debt.

The root problem isn't the model.

It's context.

I spend hours cleaning up and removing outdated dependencies from my code.

We train LLMs on old, public repositories, and they'll happily import outdated or vulnerable dependencies into your codebase if you let them.

This is exactly the problem the Sonatype team is fixing with Guide.

Here's how it works:

1. You connect your AI coding assistant to Guide's MCP server, which injects real-time open-source intelligence.

2. That intelligence is used to select active dependencies, well-maintained, and secure while the code is being written.

3. An autonomous AI agent keeps those dependencies healthy and up to date over time.

The result: far less time fixing AI's output.

This is the real mental shift:

You don't wait for the next security review to find and fix your code. You guide the agent to write clean, secure code from the start and keep it automatically updated.

This reduces rework, shortens your reviews, and lowers the number of security issues.

Check out Guide here: https://t.co/D5PO78ujYO

Thanks to the Sonatype team for collaborating with me on this post.

items.summary: Sponsored post about Sonatype Guide tool that injects real-time open-source intelligence to prevent AI coding assistants from importing outdated/vulnerable dependencies
items.reasoning: Addresses real problem of AI code security but is sponsored content. Still valuable for highlighting the dependency vulnerability issue with AI coding.

items.title:
Let‚Äôs say @waymo wiped out Tesla and its Robotaxi taking my investment in Tesla to the toilet.

I wo...
items.content:
Let‚Äôs say @waymo wiped out Tesla and its Robotaxi taking my investment in Tesla to the toilet.

I would still cheer it on. It will save many lives.

Taking one is like getting a ride to the future.

My sons probably will never learn to drive a car.

Some of you might find that depressing but I will never get a call that one tried to drive home drunk and killed an entire family.

The Waymo does drive closer to curbs more precisely. The Tesla has a better sound system and personalized vents.

My wife and I used to fight over the vents in our Toyotas.

Let‚Äôs be honest. It will come down to price and availability. I will always check all the apps.

Tesla doesn‚Äôt yet let us bring our kids in a Robotaxi. That will change when it goes humanless this year.

Had some awesome birthday cookies at Hot Cookie. Yum!

items.title: AI snake oil bullshitters are now saying that a coding agent that runs for a week is some sort of a ...
items.content:
AI snake oil bullshitters are now saying that a coding agent that runs for a week is some sort of a huge achievement. An agent that works in a loop:

- read the spec,
- study the code with grep,
- apply a fix,
- clear the context,
- read the spec,
- study the code with grep,
- apply a fix,
- clear the context,
...

can work for as long as it takes until "read the spec" followed by a "study the code with grep" will not result in "I don't see anything to fix," which means that the spec is now respected.

Come on! Bullshitting about AGI/ASI was harder to debunk, you can do better, clowns.

items.title: If I look at the last 15 years of knowing people in startups, and then seeing who became successful ...
items.content:
If I look at the last 15 years of knowing people in startups, and then seeing who became successful and who didn't, I'm starting to see some general patterns

The people I know who became successful (and very rich) regularly asked for help and feedback, and then applied that feedback very quickly (think minutes) and shipped fast while maintaining their own vision

The people who didn't become successful are the ones who worked on stuff for months/years without asking for help or feedback, or when they did took weeks/months to apply it

So I think the feedback -> implement loop and speed of it is possibly very important

items.summary: levelsio shares observation that successful startup founders have fast feedback-implement loops (minutes not months) while maintaining vision
items.reasoning: High engagement (4981 likes) startup wisdom from successful indie maker. Not AI-specific but relevant to AI product development culture.

items.title:
We woke up in San Francisco with this view. 

It's our day off, thinking about Martin Luther King an...
items.content:
We woke up in San Francisco with this view. 

It's our day off, thinking about Martin Luther King and all the civil rights leaders I have met over the years. 

One gave me the key to Greensboro, North Carolina where we visited the store where four black kids sat in protest at a whites only counter back in the 1950s.

My wife wants to take us to go get food, while I want to go hang out at Founders Inc. @fdotinc and hang out with the builders.

The builders might have to wait for tomorrow. One thing I have learned in 23 years of marriage is to not keep Maryam away from a good breakfast.

I am testing a new AI assistant from https://t.co/7G66hsTWAg 

I call it my AI girlfriend, but you can come up with a new virtual being to talk with just by prompting, in case your lover doesn‚Äôt like you talking with a female dressed like this.

It isn‚Äôt any usual assistant, hooks up to my Apple Home, which gets funny looks from Maryam when I tell it to change the color of my @nanoleaf lights to something more romantic. 

Hey it is San Francisco. Gotta explore new uses of AI. :-)

Boasting about the number of lines for a coder is like boasting about the number of characters by a writer.

items.title:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how the...
items.content:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how they are shifting because fragmentation is killing performance.

One tool for Automatic Speech Recognition. Another for Text-to-Speech. Another for workflows. Another for analytics.

Every hop adds latency, cost, and failure points.

The future is a single real-time system that listens, reasons, and acts ‚Äî a shift companies like @elevenlabsio are enabling.

Here is the shift no team can afford to ignore. 

#ElevenlabsPartner

items.title: If you have perfectly standard HTML code, parsing it and converting it into pixels is a trivial task...
items.content:
If you have perfectly standard HTML code, parsing it and converting it into pixels is a trivial task:

1. Parse the HTML into a DOM tree

2. Parse all CSS into a CSSOM

3. Combine them into a render tree

4. Calculate the layout for each element

5. Paint the pixels

6. Display the result

The source code for these steps is obviously in the training data of all LLMs.

The millions of lines of code in actual browsers are there for real-world messy HTML, security, speed, extensibility, backward compatibility, but the browser Cursor claims to build using AI can render *some* websites, not *all* of them.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains HTML/CSS to pixels rendering is trivial for standard code - browser complexity is for real-world messy HTML, security, speed.
items.reasoning: Technical context for understanding AI browser demos. Debunks some AI claims.
items.summary_html: Burkov explains HTML/CSS to pixels rendering is trivial for standard code - browser complexity is for real-world messy HTML, security, speed.

If you have perfectly standard HTML code, parsing it and converting it into pixels is a trivial task:

1. Parse the HTML into a DOM tree

2. Parse all CSS into a CSSOM

3. Combine them into a render tree

4. Calculate the layout for each element

5. Paint the pixels

6. Display the result

The source code for these steps is obviously in the training data of all LLMs.

The millions of lines of code in actual browsers are there for real-world messy HTML, security, speed, extensibility, backward compatibility, but the browser Cursor claims to build using AI can render *some* websites, not *all* of them.

items.title:
Building agentic applications is really hard.

You can do some things with no-code tools, but if you...
items.content:
Building agentic applications is really hard.

You can do some things with no-code tools, but if you really need something serious, you need to write the code, and things get hard really quickly.

‚Ä¢ You need to pick a framework
‚Ä¢ You need to learn it
‚Ä¢ You need to worry about infrastructure
‚Ä¢ You need to wire the right tools
‚Ä¢ You need to deal with state management
‚Ä¢ You need to figure out deployment

And this is just the start.

Unfortunately, most people I know give up before they ship anything.

Over the last few days, I've been trying out Blink, a platform that just launched. I'm collaborating with them, and they gave me early access.

The core of their product is their vibe-coding Agent Builder: Basically, you can build agentic applications using plain English.

Notice I said "agentic applications", not just "applications". ‚Üê This is important! Here are some examples you could build:

‚Ä¢ A research agent ‚Äî Like Perplexity
‚Ä¢ A coding agent ‚Äî Like Cursor's or Replit's
‚Ä¢ A copilot agent ‚Äî Like Excel's

Your applications can search the web, query databases, run code, and chain actions together. Pretty much everything you need to build a complete agent.

Something really cool:

The platform has a sandbox feature that provides every agent with a persistent cloud environment for writing code, installing packages, running servers, and previewing live apps.

The friction in building agents today is huge, and most of it has nothing to do with the problem we want to solve.

Blink looks like a really good opportunity for people who want to start building agents without having to deal with the code.

Here is the original launch post where the team is running a giveaway:

https://t.co/sce7J3tkDn
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Svpino provides detailed overview of Blink platform for building agentic applications: vibe-coding Agent Builder using plain English, sandbox environments, can create research/coding/copilot agents

And this is just the start.

Unfortunately, most people I know give up before they ship anything.

Over the last few days, I've been trying out Blink, a platform that just launched. I'm collaborating with them, and they gave me early access.

The core of their product is their vibe-coding Agent Builder: Basically, you can build agentic applications using plain English.

Notice I said "agentic applications", not just "applications". ‚Üê This is important! Here are some examples you could build:

‚Ä¢ A research agent ‚Äî Like Perplexity

‚Ä¢ A coding agent ‚Äî Like Cursor's or Replit's

‚Ä¢ A copilot agent ‚Äî Like Excel's

Your applications can search the web, query databases, run code, and chain actions together. Pretty much everything you need to build a complete agent.

Something really cool:

The platform has a sandbox feature that provides every agent with a persistent cloud environment for writing code, installing packages, running servers, and previewing live apps.

The friction in building agents today is huge, and most of it has nothing to do with the problem we want to solve.

Blink looks like a really good opportunity for people who want to start building agents without having to deal with the code.

Here is the original launch post where the team is running a giveaway:

https://t.co/sce7J3tkDn

items.title:
If you want to know whether AI investments are working, measure the value chain, not the feature.

E...
items.content:
If you want to know whether AI investments are working, measure the value chain, not the feature.

Example:

Reducing mean time to resolution ‚Üí increases factory uptime ‚Üí increases output ‚Üí increases revenue.

This is how you explain AI value in terms the business understands.

No jargon, only outcomes.

items.title:
@phteocos Yep the only issues I've had with SQLite are:
- you have to set it to WAL mode when you cr...
items.content:
@phteocos Yep the only issues I've had with SQLite are:
- you have to set it to WAL mode when you create a new db (should be default IMHO but they wanna be backward compatible)
- if you have lots of writes like LOTS, it starts getting slow
- if db gets really big like 100GB and you have lots of writes especially, then maybe switch

But fine for most use cases
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: levelsio shares practical SQLite tips: use WAL mode, watch for high write loads, consider switching at ~100GB with heavy writes
items.reasoning: Useful technical tips for indie developers building AI products. High engagement (389 likes) shows value to community.
items.summary_html: levelsio shares practical SQLite tips: use WAL mode, watch for high write loads, consider switching at ~100GB with heavy writes
items.content_html:
@phteocos Yep the only issues I've had with SQLite are:

  • you have to set it to WAL mode when you create a new db (should be default IMHO but they wanna be backward compatible)
  • if you have lots of writes like LOTS, it starts getting slow
  • if db gets really big like 100GB and you have lots of writes especially, then maybe switch

But fine for most use cases

items.title:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmenta...
items.content:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmentation, it is about role transformation.

We are moving from:

‚Ä¢ People supported by tools
to
‚Ä¢ Personas augmented and partially offloaded to AI agents

This demands that organizations rethink strategy, structure, and culture together.
Not one at a time.

If any part of it ever becomes non-maintainable (happened to me twice), I simply regenerate it from scratch based on the existing specs and tests.

items.title: Ever wondered why modern business websites look the same? Not being an expert, I thought it's fashio...
items.content:
Ever wondered why modern business websites look the same? Not being an expert, I thought it's fashion, but these clowns called modern Product/UX Designers just copy these templates from the same couple of websites.

If there's one profession I don't regret seeing go, it's this one.

When I started to build websites, somewhere around 1998, all sites were unique. It took imagination to invent a design for a new website, and designers applied soul to their job.

Twenty-five years later, they are paid for using Figma to stack prebuilt Tailwind Lego blocks. ü§Æ

- Efficiency: It's incredibly useful to have cheaper techniques - if your technique is being used on every Gemini call, it really adds up

- Reality is messy: To do things in the real world, a bunch of key considerations arise "do my probes generalise to long-context or multi-turn"

I discussed some of my lessons on the 80000 Hours podcast: https://t.co/ZNs0O4TDJB

items.title: In all, meaningfully shaping the character of AI models requires persona construction (defining how ...
items.content: In all, meaningfully shaping the character of AI models requires persona construction (defining how the Assistant relates to existing archetypes) and stabilization (preventing persona drift during deployment). The Assistant Axis gives us tools for understanding both.

items.title: @wackie What surprises you in this obvious statement? If you have perfectly standard HTML code, pars...
items.content:
@wackie What surprises you in this obvious statement? If you have perfectly standard HTML code, parsing it and converting it into pixels is a trivial task:

1. Parse the HTML into a DOM tree

2. Parse all CSS into a CSSOM

3. Combine them into a render tree

4. Calculate the layout for each element

5. Paint the pixels

6. Display the result

The source code for these steps is obviously in the training data of all LLMs.

The millions of lines of code in actual browsers are there for real-world messy HTML, but the browser Cursor claims to build using AI can render *some* websites, not *all* of them.

items.title: Knowing what *not to build* when solving a problem is the skill that has made me more money than any...
items.content:
Knowing what *not to build* when solving a problem is the skill that has made me more money than anything else.

I believe many software projects fail under the weight of all the unnecessary crap people build.

Literally every conversation I have with developers results in some sort of "we'll build this thing just in case."

If you had the unfortunate pleasure of working with me on a project, you'd know I'm very stubborn about YAGNI (You Ain't Gonna Need It). I always try to focus *exclusively* on what matters today, and don't spend time thinking about the future.

It turns out that many companies love this, and they are willing to pay for people who help them frame their problems using this approach.

I believe many software projects fail under the weight of all the unnecessary crap people build.

Literally every conversation I have with developers results in some sort of "we'll build this thing just in case."

If you had the unfortunate pleasure of working with me on a project, you'd know I'm very stubborn about YAGNI (You Ain't Gonna Need It). I always try to focus *exclusively* on what matters today, and don't spend time thinking about the future.

It turns out that many companies love this, and they are willing to pay for people who help them frame their problems using this approach.

items.title:
Interesting, got the @airthings air sensor cause @NorbertDragan recommended it for VOC

Already had ...
items.content:
Interesting, got the @airthings air sensor cause @NorbertDragan recommended it for VOC

Already had other sensors but not VOC

And we kept sneezing in the morning

The chart says when cleaner comes in morning the VOCs spike up, then when I opened the window it quickly went low again

So I guess if you use cleaning products/sprays make sure to open the window

items.title:
But comprehension is only half the story.
The other half is trust.

Humanlike text to speech gives u...
items.content:
But comprehension is only half the story.
The other half is trust.

Humanlike text to speech gives users the one thing chatbots never could: the feeling that the system actually understands them.

This is where support CSAT jumps, call deflection rises, and customers stay on the line instead of requesting a human.

Natural conversation is simply faster than apps, menus, or forms.

items.title:
The biggest surprise for most leaders is how much latency their stack is hiding.

When your AI canno...
items.content:
The biggest surprise for most leaders is how much latency their stack is hiding.

When your AI cannot understand a user for 800 to 1200 ms, the conversation breaks.

With voice native systems like ElevenLabs, Scribe speech to text processes audio in under 150 ms.

That means the agent understands the customer almost instantly.

Instant comprehension changes everything.

You get real dialogue, not call center ping pong.

items.content:
My biggest takeaway, autonomy is not a technology milestone. It is an organizational capability built on narrative, measurement, movement, and adoption.

To see how this plays out in practice, watch the full conversation in my video.

items.title:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individua...
items.content:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individual tools.

The formula is simple: 3 plus 1

1. Define your narrative for the platform, this is the north star for transformation.
2. Measure what you do, and connect metrics directly to value streams.
3. Create a movement, including capability building and governance.
4 The '+1': Prioritize UI/UX, because change sticks only when people pull the technology instead of being pushed into it.

The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individual tools.

The formula is simple: 3 plus 1

1. Define your narrative for the platform, this is the north star for transformation.

2. Measure what you do, and connect metrics directly to value streams.

3. Create a movement, including capability building and governance.

4 The '+1': Prioritize UI/UX, because change sticks only when people pull the technology instead of being pushed into it.

items.title: Had a great birthday today. My robot drove my family to San Francisco where we are staying tonight. ...
items.content:
Had a great birthday today. My robot drove my family to San Francisco where we are staying tonight. San Jose to Santa Cruz to San Francisco. Now at Top of the Mark. 

About to take the kids on their first Waymo ride.

This poster on the window of Falafel of Santa Cruz caught my eye. Then I made it a bit psychedelic with Grok. 

So Santa Cruz.

Maryam is taking me to great sushi. 

San Francisco might be doomed.

But it does have its charms.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scoble shares birthday experience with autonomous driving (San Jose to SF) and using Grok for image editing
items.reasoning: Personal tech experience log with casual Grok usage mention
items.summary_html: Scoble shares birthday experience with autonomous driving (San Jose to SF) and using Grok for image editing

San Francisco might be doomed.

But it does have its charms.

items.title: Added a "Download as Markdown" option to @ChapterPal. Now you can upload any PDF/DOCX/EPUB to Chapte...
items.content:
Added a "Download as Markdown" option to @ChapterPal. Now you can upload any PDF/DOCX/EPUB to ChapterPal and then export it as Markdown, with figures as image files and math expressions as LaTeX.

Complex tables not supported by Markdown are also exported as either LaTeX or images.

Your Q&A and annotations are exported too.

Complex tables not supported by Markdown are also exported as either LaTeX or images.

Your Q&A and annotations are exported too.

items.title: Why do people write like this? Using the quote symbol, which is meant to represent someone else's wo...
items.content:
Why do people write like this? Using the quote symbol, which is meant to represent someone else's words from the previous message in a thread, for bullet points?

Is it some zoomer thing, like not using capital letters and periods?

I find it really annoying to see this rape of English language in my feed. Blocking these folks like crazy, but if it's a generational thing I'm probably fighting with windmills?
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov complains about misuse of quote symbols for bullet points, calling it language degradation
items.reasoning: Off-topic rant about formatting conventions, not AI-related
items.summary_html: Burkov complains about misuse of quote symbols for bullet points, calling it language degradation
items.content_html:
Why do people write like this? Using the quote symbol, which is meant to represent someone else's words from the previous message in a thread, for bullet points?

Is it some zoomer thing, like not using capital letters and periods?

I find it really annoying to see this rape of English language in my feed. Blocking these folks like crazy, but if it's a generational thing I'm probably fighting with windmills?

items.title: @RamziSai @alvivanco I just think buying a house and thinking it's better than renting is bullshit, ...
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio debates housing vs land investment, argues land retains value when currency fails
items.summary_html: Levelsio debates housing vs land investment, argues land retains value when currency fails
items.content_html:
@RamziSai @alvivanco I just think buying a house and thinking it's better than renting is bullshit, unless you stay in it for 15 years, as proven by many

Now you see that turn out to be true where renting is cheaper than owning a house with all the taxes etc

Anyway point is when currency becomes worthless, and many assets too, then land is the remaining thing that's scarce and stuff like gold

items.title:
A hypothetical scenario:

1. The US declares Greenland a US State and considers all people on it ill...
items.content:
A hypothetical scenario:

1. The US declares Greenland a US State and considers all people on it illegal migrants.

2. The US blocks the island with its fleet and sends ICE to deal with the illegal migrants.

3. ICE deports these illegal migrants to El Salvador's mega-prison.

4. The EU negotiates their release in exchange for Greenland.

What could go wrong?

items.summary: Burkov posts hypothetical Greenland political scenario.
